title: Ivan Georgievich Petrovskii
description: Born 18 January 1901. He is a Russian mathematician who worked on partial differential equations. His main contribution was on the theory of partial differential equations, topology of algebraic curves and surfaces, and probability. Petrovsky also worked on the boundary value problem for the heat equation and this was applied to both probability theory and work of Kolmogorov
subject: Russia; partial differential; differential; Sevsk
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Petr Sergeevich Novikov
description: Born 15 August 1901. He is a Russian mathematician with contributions in the field of group theory (combinatorial problems, word problem for groups, and the Burnside problem). In 1952 he showed that word problem for groups is insoluble. Before entering university, he joined the Red Army under Trotsky.
subject: Russian; Red Army; Moscow; group theory
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Werner Karl Heisenberg
description: Born 5 December 1901. He worked on Quantum Mechanics, and nuclear physics. He belonged to a paramilitary organization. He also played chess and was proficient at it. He was awarded in 1932 a Nobel Prize in Physics for the creation of quantum mechanics.
subject: German; quantum mechanics; Heisenberg uncertainty principle
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Richard Dagobert Brauer
description: Born 10 February 1901. He worked on group characters. He created a method to classify all finite simple groups. Brauer went to Harvard wehn he was 51 years old, and half of his total publications were published after this. He also collaborated with Weyl, creating a joint paper on spinors, which became the background for Dirac's work on the theory of the spinning electron within quantum mechanics.
subject: German; finite simple groups; Harvard
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Naum Il'ich Akhiezer
description: Born 6 March 1901. He is known for his work on function theory, and approximation theory, and on the history of mathematics. He published many papers in Russian, French, and German in Kiev University. He solved the problem of finding the polynomial with three fixed coefficients deviating least from zero on a given interval.
subject: Russian; function theory; approximation theory
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Abraham Wald
description: Born 31 October 1902. He was born in Hungary (now Romania) and worked on decision theory, geometry, and econometrics. He was a mathematics tutor to Karl Schlesinger, a leading Austrian banker and economist. It was this stint that increased his interest in economics. He worked on military projects after 1941 in Columbia. His most important work points out that the two major problems of statistical theory at that time, testing hypotheses and estimation, can both be regarded as simple special cases of a more general problem - known nowadays as a "statistical decision problem". He defines loss functions, risk functions, a priori distributions, Bayes decision rules, admissible decision rules, and minimax decision rules, and proves that a minimax decision rule has a constant risk under certain regularity conditions.
subject: Hungarian; decision theory, statistics, economics
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Kazimierz Zarankiewicz
description: Born 2 May 1902. He was a Polish mathematician who contributed to topology. Topology was a new discipline in the newly liberated environment the mathematician was in. He did important work in topology and graph theory. He wrote on complex functions and number thoery as well.
subject: Polish; topology; number theory
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Alfred Tarski
description: Born 14 January 1901. He worked in many areas of mathematics. These were metamathematics, set theory, measure theory, model theory, and general algebra. He published a joint paper with Banach in that year (1924) on what is now called the Banach-Tarski paradox. The result proves that a sphere can be cut into a finite number of pieces and then reassembled into a sphere of larger size, or alternatively it can be reassembled into two spheres of equal size to the original one
subject: Polish; topology; number theory; Banach-Tarksi paradox
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac
description:
Born 8 August 1902. He is a creator of the complete theoretical formulation on quantum mechanics. He realised that Heisenberg's uncertainty principle was a statement of the noncommutativity of the quantum mechanical observables. Dirac had eleven papers already in print before submitting his doctoral dissertation. It has been said in jest that his spoken vocabulary consisted of "Yes", "No", and "I don't know. He once said:-
I was taught at school never to start a sentence without knowing the end of it.
subject: British; quantum mechanics;
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Frank Plumpton Ramsey
description: Born 22 February 1903. He is known for his work on the foundatons of mathematics and philosophy, and the Ramsey theory in combinatorics. He published his first major work The Foundations of Mathematics in 1925.
subject: British; Ramsey theory; combinatorics
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: John von Neumann
description: Born 28 December 1903.  He worked on asolid framework for quantum mechanics. He also contibuted to game theory, von Neumann Algebras, and in computer science. At the age of six, he was able to exchange jokes with his father in ancient greek, when it came to memorisation he was a prodigy. He had a unique lifestyle, and enjoyed partying. In game theory von Neumann proved the minimax theorem.
subject: Hungarian; quantum mechanics; game theory
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Aurel Wintner
description: Born 8 April 1903. He is known for his work on number theory, differential equations, probability, and celestial mechanics. From 1924 to 1927 he published around 20 papers on astronomy and mathematics. He published the first proofs of the basic facts about Hilbert spaces in 1929. He played an important role in developing the editorial policy of the American Journal of Mathematics.
subject: Hungarian; number theory; differential equations; probability; and celestial mechanics
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Jean Frédéric Auguste Delsarte
description:
Born
19 October 1903. He worked on mathematical analysis. Delsarte is best known for his work on mean periodic functions and translation operators, but he was an analyst of great power and originality, which he applied to many problems.
subject: French; mathematical analysis
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: William Vallance Douglas Hodge
description: Born 17 June 1903. He worked on Algebraic Geometry and Differential Geometry. Hodge was one of the originators of the British Mathematical Colloquium, an annual conference which visits different British universities. He was described as: unlike the conventional picture of a mathematician. Jovial, informal and down-to-earth, he could easily have passed for a businessman.
subject: Scott; geometry
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Andrei Nicolaevich Kolmogoroff
description: Born 25 April 1903. He is one of the pioneers of probability theory. He also worked on the motion of planets, and air turbulence. Gnedenko wrote about Kologorov: almost simultaneously [Kolmogorov] exhibited his interest in a number of other areas of classical analysis: in problems of differentiation and integration, in measures of sets etc. In every one of his papers, dealing with such a variety of topics, he introduced an element of originality, a breadth of approach, and a depth of thought.
subject: Russian; probability theory; celestial bodies; air flow
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Alonzo Church
description: Born 14 June 1903. He contributed to mathematical logic and theoretical computer science. He created the λ-calculus in the 1930's which today is an invaluable tool for computer scientists.
subject: American; mathematical logic; computer science; symbolic logic
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Witold Hurewicz
description: Born 29 June 1904. Is known for his contributions to algebraic topology, and discovering higher homotopy groups. His brother Stefan emigrated to the United States via the Philippines in January 1941, which was a common route to avoid persecution. He contributed to military efforts with research on applied mathematics, specifically servomechanisms.
subject: Polish; topology; migrate
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: John Henry Constantine Whitehead
description: Born 11 November 1904. He is remembered for his work in topology, and in homotopy equivalence. In Oxford he had many interests, including sports. He met G H Hardy through this subject. He collaborated with Lefschetz in proving that all analytic manifolds can be triangulated. In this area he is best remembered for his work on homotopy equivalence.
subject: Indian; British; homotopy equivalence; topology
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Philip Hall
description: Born 11 April 1904. He is one of the pioneers for the British school of group theory, and its growth in the 20th century is attributed to him. He wrote A contribution to the theory of groups of prime power order ehich is asaid to be one of the fundamental sources of modern group theory.
subject: British; group theory; pioneer
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Lev Genrikhovich Shnireman
description: Born 2 January 1905. He is known for his work on the Goldbach conjecture. In 1930 Shnirelman introduced important new ideas into number theory. Using these ideas of compactness of a sequence of natural numbers he was able to prove a weak form of the Goldbach conjecture showing that every number can be written as a sum of at most CC primes where CC is a definite number.
subject: Belarussian; Goldbach conjecture
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Abraham Adrian Albert
description: Born 9 November 1905. He is known for his work associative and non associative algebras. He looked at Riemann matrices and worked in the subject, producing the theory of complex manifolds and Albert went on to write an important series of papers on these questions over the following years.
subject: American; associative and non-associative algebras; complex manifolds
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: László Kalmár
description: Born 27 March 1905. Acknowledged as the leader of mathematical logic, he worked on this topic, and theoretical computer science. He worked on mathematical logic solving certain cases of the decision problem for the first order predicate calculus, simplified results of Bernays, and worked on ideas of Post, Gödel and Church.
subject: Hungarian; mathematical logic; computer science
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Ruth Moufang
description: Born 10 January 1905. She is known for her work on Moufang planes, and Moufang loops. In her graduate work, she transported the axioms David Hilbert had postulated for the realm of plane geometry into the field of projective geometry. She was modest when talking about her own work, and she also had many intellectual interests outside mathematics.
subject: German; geometry
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Charles Ehresmann
description: Born 19 April 1905. He worked in differential topology and category theory. Dieudonné describes Ehresmann's personality as "distinguished by forthrightness, simplicity, and total absence of conceit or careerism. As a teacher he was outstanding, not so much for the brilliance of his lectures as for the inspiration and tireless guidance he generously gave to his research students."
subject: French; topology
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Stanislaw Mazur
description: Born 1 January 1905. He is known for his work in functional analysis, summability theory, infinite games and computable functions. He collaborated with Banach and Ulam.
subject: Austrian; infinite games; summability theory; functional analysis; computable functions
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Karol Borsuk
description: Born 8 May 1905. He made important contributions to topology. He invented the theory of retracts, published in Sur les rétractes. In Lwów Borsuk joined the mathematicians in the Scottish Café and contributed to the open problems which they wrote down in the famous book (Scottish Book). He influenced strongly the development of the whole area of infinite-dimensional topology with his theory of retracts and his theory of shape which became major topics for discussion at his seminar.
subject: Polish; topology
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Jean A. Dieudonné
description: Born 1 July 1906. He is remembered for his work in general topology, topological vector spaces, algebraic geometry, invariant theory and the classical groups. He founded Bourbaki and also wrote on the history of mathematics. He wrote about the history of mathematics. A text he produced is "The History of functional analysis" which "is a detailed and absorbing account of the history and development of functional analysis, beginning with Lagrange and Daniel Bernoulli, through the work of Fredholm, Hilbert, and Frigyes Riesz at the turn of this century, and ending about 1960."
subject: French; topology; Bourbaki; geometry
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Samuel Stanley Wilks
description: Born 17 June 1906. He is remembered for his work in mathematical statistics. His undergraduate endeavors included architechture and industrial arts, and mathematics. He pblished two high quality papers "The standard error of the means of 'matched' samples (1931)" and his thesis, "On the distributions of statistics in samples from a normal population of two variables with matched sampling of one variable."
subject: American; statistics
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Alexandr Osipovich Gelfond
description: Born 24 October 1906. He developed basic techniques in the study of transcendental numbers. His major contributions to transcendental numbers is set out in Transcendentnye algebraicheskie chisla Ⓣ (1952). In it Gelfond states that his aims are "to show the contemporary state of the theory of transcendental numbers, to exhibit the fundamental methods of this theory, to present the historical course of development of these methods, and to show the connections which exist between this theory and other problems in the theory of numbers."
subject: Russian; transcedental numbers
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: William Feller
description: Born 7 July 1906. He worked on probability and is best known as the author of a standard work on Statistics. "Grundbegriffe der Wahrscheinlichkeitsrechnung" his monograph, published in 1933, built up probability theory in a rigorous way from fundamental axioms in a way comparable to Euclid's Elements.
subject: Croatian; statistics
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Kurt Friedrich Gödel
description: Born 28 April 1906. Gödel proved fundamental results about axiomatic systems showing in any axiomatic mathematical system there are propositions that cannot be proved or disproved within the axioms of the system.
subject: Austrian-Hungarian; axioms; axiomatic system
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.

title: Grace Murray Hopper
description: Born 9 December 1906. She is one of the pioneers in the development of the electronic computer, and also the only mathematician with a warship named after her. Hopper was awarded her doctorate by Yale University in 1934 for a thesis New Types of Irreducibility Criteria. She eventually persuaded the Naval Reserve (US Navy) to accept her in 1943 and she also persuaded Vassar College to grant her leave. Hopper was working on the Harvard Mark II computer. It was in this machine that the first actual "computer bug" was found: a moth which shorted one of the 17 000 relays in the machine. She designed an improved compiler while working for the company and was part of the team which developed Flow-Matic, the first English-language data-processing compiler.
subject: American; computer science; computer
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes.
